quoteLast: Stuart rose and said: "Gentlemen, in twenty-five minutes the time agreed upon will have expired."
title: Round the World in Eighty Days
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Frith, Henry, 1840- [Translator]

quoteFirst: Master and man then descended, the street door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross. The cab stopped before the railway station at
quoteLast: . Passepartout jumped off the box and followed his master, who, after paying the cabman, was about to enter the station, when a poor beggar woman, with a child in her arms, approached him. Her naked feet were smeared with mud, her head covered with a wretched bonnet, from which hung a tattered feather, and her shoulders shrouded in a ragged shawl.
title: Around the World in Eighty Days. Junior Deluxe Edition
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteLast: , the Sapper's Hill signaller had reported more smoke on the horizon; and, a quarter of an hour later, as the _Kent_ steamed to the harbour entrance, the captain of the _Canopus_ reported this to be proceeding from two ships about twenty miles off, the two first sighted {66} being now little more than eight miles away.

quoteFirst: Camp 22. Wind from east by north and cloudy; obliged to lighten further our load by leaving the tents and spare pack-saddles and bags here on north side of creek; started at
quoteLast: The barrier here is composed of a yellow close-grained stone impregnated with small specks of quartz, and the hills on either side, pieces of granite of the same kind are also strewed in the bed, brought down by the currents. A few oak-trees immediately above this camp.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia

quoteLast: the 164th Infantry Brigade began its advance on a two-battalion frontage. The right front was formed by the 1/4th North Lancashire Regiment with the Battalion in support, and touch was to be kept on the right with battalions of the 45th Brigade (15th Division); the left front was formed by the 2/5th Lancashire Fusiliers supported by the 1/8th Liverpool (Irish).

title: From the Indus to the Tigris

quoteFirst: Very cold during the night, but beautiful morning. This river runs parallel to the Burdekin for some distance and at only a very short distance between. Started at
quoteLast: over the basalt ridges for the sake of better travelling than we are likely to have in the Burdekin, for some distance at least. South for one mile, then east-south-east through open forest with basalt blocks occasionally, and rather swampy-inclined land for two and three-quarter miles.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia

quoteLast: , and both the red and the blue lines were captured in succession half-an-hour ahead of scheduled time. This capture covered the whole length of my front except the extreme left, where a half expected difficulty arose, but one which exercised no influence upon the day's success.

quoteFirst: Thomas Wilson, scythe-maker, of Brincliffe-hill, said he was outside the Banner-cross Hotel about
quoteLast: on the night of the 29th of November, when he heard two reports from a revolver. The sound came from Gregory’s house, and on looking that way he saw a man run across the road from the end of Bannercross-terrace and get over the wall on the opposite side.
title: Charles Peace, or The Adventures of a Notorious Burglar
